17  package org.springframework.core.env;
18  
19  import java.util.Collection;
20  import java.util.List;
21  
22  import org.springframework.util.StringUtils;
23  
24  /**
25   * Abstract base class for {@link PropertySource} implementations backed by command line
26   * arguments. The parameterized type {@code T} represents the underlying source of command
27   * line options. This may be as simple as a String array in the case of
28   * {@link SimpleCommandLinePropertySource}, or specific to a particular API such as JOpt's
29   * {@code OptionSet} in the case of {@link JOptCommandLinePropertySource}.
30   *
31   * <h3>Purpose and General Usage</h3>
32   * For use in standalone Spring-based applications, i.e. those that are bootstrapped via
33   * a traditional {@code main} method accepting a {@code String[]} of arguments from the
34   * command line. In many cases, processing command-line arguments directly within the
35   * {@code main} method may be sufficient, but in other cases, it may be desirable to
36   * inject arguments as values into Spring beans. It is this latter set of cases in which
37   * a {@code CommandLinePropertySource} becomes useful. A {@code CommandLinePropertySource}
38   * will typically be added to the {@link Environment} of the Spring
39   * {@code ApplicationContext}, at which point all command line arguments become available
40   * through the {@link Environment#getProperty(String)} family of methods. For example:
41   * <pre class="code">
42   * public static void main(String[] args) {
43   *     CommandLinePropertySource clps = ...;
44   *     AnnotationConfigApplicationContext ctx = new AnnotationConfigApplicationContext();
45   *     ctx.getEnvironment().getPropertySources().addFirst(clps);
46   *     ctx.register(AppConfig.class);
47   *     ctx.refresh();
48   * }</pre>
49   * With the bootstrap logic above, the {@code AppConfig} class may {@code @Inject} the
50   * Spring {@code Environment} and query it directly for properties:
51   * <pre class="code">
52   * &#064;Configuration
53   * public class AppConfig {
54   *     &#064;Inject Environment env;
55   *
56   *     &#064;Bean
57   *     public void DataSource dataSource() {
58   *         MyVendorDataSource dataSource = new MyVendorDataSource();
59   *         dataSource.setHostname(env.getProperty("db.hostname", "localhost"));
60   *         dataSource.setUsername(env.getRequiredProperty("db.username"));
61   *         dataSource.setPassword(env.getRequiredProperty("db.password"));
62   *         // ...
63   *         return dataSource;
64   *     }
65   * }</pre>
66   * Because the {@code CommandLinePropertySource} was added to the {@code Environment}'s
67   * set of {@link MutablePropertySources} using the {@code #addFirst} method, it has
68   * highest search precedence, meaning that while "db.hostname" and other properties may
69   * exist in other property sources such as the system environment variables, it will be
70   * chosen from the command line property source first. This is a reasonable approach
71   * given that arguments specified on the command line are naturally more specific than
72   * those specified as environment variables.
73   *
74   * <p>As an alternative to injecting the {@code Environment}, Spring's {@code @Value}
75   * annotation may be used to inject these properties, given that a {@link
76   * PropertySourcesPropertyResolver} bean has been registered, either directly or through
77   * using the {@code <context:property-placeholder>} element. For example:
78   * <pre class="code">
79   * &#064;Component
80   * public class MyComponent {
81   *     &#064;Value("my.property:defaultVal")
82   *     private String myProperty;
83   *
84   *     public void getMyProperty() {
85   *         return this.myProperty;
86   *     }
87   *
88   *     // ...
89   * }</pre>
90   *
91   * <h3>Working with option arguments</h3>
92   *
93   * <p>Individual command line arguments are represented as properties through the usual
94   * {@link PropertySource#getProperty(String)} and
95   * {@link PropertySource#containsProperty(String)} methods. For example, given the
96   * following command line:
97   * <pre class="code">
98   * --o1=v1 --o2</pre>
99   * 'o1' and 'o2' are treated as "option arguments", and the following assertions would
100  * evaluate true:
101  * <pre class="code">
102  * CommandLinePropertySource<?> ps = ...
103  * assert ps.containsProperty("o1") == true;
104  * assert ps.containsProperty("o2") == true;
105  * assert ps.containsProperty("o3") == false;
106  * assert ps.getProperty("o1").equals("v1");
107  * assert ps.getProperty("o2").equals("");
108  * assert ps.getProperty("o3") == null;</pre>
109  *
110  * Note that the 'o2' option has no argument, but {@code getProperty("o2")} resolves to
111  * empty string ({@code ""}) as opposed to {@code null}, while {@code getProperty("o3")}
112  * resolves to {@code null} because it was not specified. This behavior is consistent with
113  * the general contract to be followed by all {@code PropertySource} implementations.
114  *
115  * <p>Note also that while "--" was used in the examples above to denote an option
116  * argument, this syntax may vary across individual command line argument libraries. For
117  * example, a JOpt- or Commons CLI-based implementation may allow for single dash ("-")
118  * "short" option arguments, etc.
119  *
120  * <h3>Working with non-option arguments</h3>
121  *
122  * <p>Non-option arguments are also supported through this abstraction. Any arguments
123  * supplied without an option-style prefix such as "-" or "--" are considered "non-option
124  * arguments" and available through the special {@linkplain
125  * #DEFAULT_NON_OPTION_ARGS_PROPERTY_NAME "nonOptionArgs"} property.  If multiple
126  * non-option arguments are specified, the value of this property will be a
127  * comma-delimited string containing all of the arguments. This approach ensures a simple
128  * and consistent return type (String) for all properties from a {@code
129  * CommandLinePropertySource} and at the same time lends itself to conversion when used
130  * in conjunction with the Spring {@link Environment} and its built-in {@code
131  * ConversionService}. Consider the following example:
132  * <pre class="code">
133  * --o1=v1 --o2=v2 /path/to/file1 /path/to/file2</pre>
134  * In this example, "o1" and "o2" would be considered "option arguments", while the two
135  * filesystem paths qualify as "non-option arguments".  As such, the following assertions
136  * will evaluate true:
137  * <pre class="code">
138  * CommandLinePropertySource<?> ps = ...
139  * assert ps.containsProperty("o1") == true;
140  * assert ps.containsProperty("o2") == true;
141  * assert ps.containsProperty("nonOptionArgs") == true;
142  * assert ps.getProperty("o1").equals("v1");
143  * assert ps.getProperty("o2").equals("v2");
144  * assert ps.getProperty("nonOptionArgs").equals("/path/to/file1,/path/to/file2");</pre>
145  *
146  * <p>As mentioned above, when used in conjunction with the Spring {@code Environment}
147  * abstraction, this comma-delimited string may easily be converted to a String array or
148  * list:
149  * <pre class="code">
150  * Environment env = applicationContext.getEnvironment();
151  * String[] nonOptionArgs = env.getProperty("nonOptionArgs", String[].class);
152  * assert nonOptionArgs[0].equals("/path/to/file1");
153  * assert nonOptionArgs[1].equals("/path/to/file2");</pre>
154  *
155  * <p>The name of the special "non-option arguments" property may be customized through
156  * the {@link #setNonOptionArgsPropertyName(String)} method. Doing so is recommended as
157  * it gives proper semantic value to non-option arguments. For example, if filesystem
158  * paths are being specified as non-option arguments, it is likely preferable to refer to
159  * these as something like "file.locations" than the default of "nonOptionArgs":
160  * <pre class="code">
161  * public static void main(String[] args) {
162  *     CommandLinePropertySource clps = ...;
163  *     clps.setNonOptionArgsPropertyName("file.locations");
164  *
165  *     AnnotationConfigApplicationContext ctx = new AnnotationConfigApplicationContext();
166  *     ctx.getEnvironment().getPropertySources().addFirst(clps);
167  *     ctx.register(AppConfig.class);
168  *     ctx.refresh();
169  * }</pre>
170  *
171  * <h3>Limitations</h3>
172  * This abstraction is not intended to expose the full power of underlying command line
173  * parsing APIs such as JOpt or Commons CLI. It's intent is rather just the opposite: to
174  * provide the simplest possible abstraction for accessing command line arguments
175  * <em>after</em> they have been parsed. So the typical case will involve fully configuring
176  * the underlying command line parsing API, parsing the {@code String[]} of arguments
177  * coming into the main method, and then simply providing the parsing results to an
178  * implementation of {@code CommandLinePropertySource}. At that point, all arguments can
179  * be considered either 'option' or 'non-option' arguments and as described above can be
180  * accessed through the normal {@code PropertySource} and {@code Environment} APIs.
181  *
182  * @author Chris Beams
183  * @since 3.1
184  * @see PropertySource
185  * @see SimpleCommandLinePropertySource
186  * @see JOptCommandLinePropertySource
187  */
188 public abstract class CommandLinePropertySource<T> extends EnumerablePropertySource<T> {
189 
190 	/** The default name given to {@link CommandLinePropertySource} instances: {@value} */
191 	public static final String COMMAND_LINE_PROPERTY_SOURCE_NAME = "commandLineArgs";
192 
193 	/** The default name of the property representing non-option arguments: {@value} */
194 	public static final String DEFAULT_NON_OPTION_ARGS_PROPERTY_NAME = "nonOptionArgs";
195 
196 
197 	private String nonOptionArgsPropertyName = DEFAULT_NON_OPTION_ARGS_PROPERTY_NAME;
198 
199 
200 	/**
201 	 * Create a new {@code CommandLinePropertySource} having the default name
202 	 * {@value #COMMAND_LINE_PROPERTY_SOURCE_NAME} and backed by the given source object.
203 	 */
204 	public CommandLinePropertySource(T source) {
205 		super(COMMAND_LINE_PROPERTY_SOURCE_NAME, source);
206 	}
207 
208 	/**
209 	 * Create a new {@link CommandLinePropertySource} having the given name
210 	 * and backed by the given source object.
211 	 */
212 	public CommandLinePropertySource(String name, T source) {
213 		super(name, source);
214 	}
215 
216 
217 	/**
218 	 * Specify the name of the special "non-option arguments" property.
219 	 * The default is {@value #DEFAULT_NON_OPTION_ARGS_PROPERTY_NAME}.
220 	 */
221 	public void setNonOptionArgsPropertyName(String nonOptionArgsPropertyName) {
222 		this.nonOptionArgsPropertyName = nonOptionArgsPropertyName;
223 	}
224 
225 	/**
226 	 * This implementation first checks to see if the name specified is the special
227 	 * {@linkplain #setNonOptionArgsPropertyName(String) "non-option arguments" property},
228 	 * and if so delegates to the abstract {@link #getNonOptionArgs()} method
229 	 * checking to see whether it returns an empty collection. Otherwise delegates to and
230 	 * returns the value of the abstract {@link #containsOption(String)} method.
231 	 */
232 	@Override
233 	public final boolean containsProperty(String name) {
234 		if (this.nonOptionArgsPropertyName.equals(name)) {
235 			return !this.getNonOptionArgs().isEmpty();
236 		}
237 		return this.containsOption(name);
238 	}
239 
240 	/**
241 	 * This implementation first checks to see if the name specified is the special
242 	 * {@linkplain #setNonOptionArgsPropertyName(String) "non-option arguments" property},
243 	 * and if so delegates to the abstract {@link #getNonOptionArgs()} method. If so
244 	 * and the collection of non-option arguments is empty, this method returns {@code
245 	 * null}. If not empty, it returns a comma-separated String of all non-option
246 	 * arguments. Otherwise delegates to and returns the result of the abstract {@link
247 	 * #getOptionValues(String)} method.
248 	 */
249 	@Override
250 	public final String getProperty(String name) {
251 		if (this.nonOptionArgsPropertyName.equals(name)) {
252 			Collection<String> nonOptionArguments = this.getNonOptionArgs();
253 			if (nonOptionArguments.isEmpty()) {
254 				return null;
255 			}
256 			else {
257 				return StringUtils.collectionToCommaDelimitedString(nonOptionArguments);
258 			}
259 		}
260 		Collection<String> optionValues = this.getOptionValues(name);
261 		if (optionValues == null) {
262 			return null;
263 		}
264 		else {
265 			return StringUtils.collectionToCommaDelimitedString(optionValues);
266 		}
267 	}
268 
269 
270 	/**
271 	 * Return whether the set of option arguments parsed from the command line contains
272 	 * an option with the given name.
273 	 */
274 	protected abstract boolean containsOption(String name);
275 
276 	/**
277 	 * Return the collection of values associated with the command line option having the
278 	 * given name.
279 	 * <ul>
280 	 * <li>if the option is present and has no argument (e.g.: "--foo"), return an empty
281 	 * collection ({@code []})</li>
282 	 * <li>if the option is present and has a single value (e.g. "--foo=bar"), return a
283 	 * collection having one element ({@code ["bar"]})</li>
284 	 * <li>if the option is present and the underlying command line parsing library
285 	 * supports multiple arguments (e.g. "--foo=bar --foo=baz"), return a collection
286 	 * having elements for each value ({@code ["bar", "baz"]})</li>
287 	 * <li>if the option is not present, return {@code null}</li>
288 	 * </ul>
289 	 */
290 	protected abstract List<String> getOptionValues(String name);
291 
292 	/**
293 	 * Return the collection of non-option arguments parsed from the command line.
294 	 * Never {@code null}.
295 	 */
296 	protected abstract List<String> getNonOptionArgs();
297 
298 }
